item.description:
I’ve always felt like I see the world a little differently. More like a system than a set of disconnected parts. I naturally think in terms of how things fit together. It’s hard for me to make sense of something without seeing the bigger picture first.

That’s probably why I’ve never quite clicked with traditional education. Most of the time, you’re expected to start from the smallest details and build your way up. But I need the “why” before the “how.” Without context, the parts just don’t mean much to me.

When you focus on work, you capitalize. When you focus on improvement, you invest. Your time is limited. Many times, you can only focus on one of them. Make sure you balance both and reconfigure your system from time to time.

I’ve always focused on building skills, believing that if I kept improving, career growth would naturally follow. I learned that while skills and career advancement are correlated, they are not the same-and one doesn’t automatically cause the other. Skill improvement is personal. Career advancement is social. Advancing your career means leveling up within the value system of the community or organization you’re part of. It’s about understanding what your stakeholders need and delivering on that. In other words, career growth depends less on how much you’ve improved, and more on how much value others perceive you bring-in their terms.
